title: mail-01.ac-cn-hongkong-c.eth.beta mailserver is not responsive
body:
### Description

*Type*: Bug

*Summary*: When app is connected to `mail-01.ac-cn-hongkong-c.eth.beta`, it can't fetch historical messages. Looks like the server is down. 

### Additional Information
* Operating System: all
@jakubgs do you know what is happening with this server? How I can check it by myself?
@cammellos the app chose this server automatically after I created an account. Is it a bug?

@lukaszfryc the app should pick a random mailserver (if you never pinned it), if the mailserver is unresponsive, and the client knows it is, it should start picking mailserver in a round-robin fashion.

> if the mailserver is unresponsive, and the client knows it is

I guess that did not work or I did not wait long enough. @cammellos what's the logic/timeout behind "the client know it"?

@lukaszfryc I think the client only checks that a connection can be established with the node, but the node might be unresponsive for other reason (long backlog of queues etc), @yenda can probably confirm as he knows that bit of code better.

It changes mail server after 2 timeouts of 30s. Is it not responsive or just very slow ? Provide some logs please. My guess is that it is just very slow because it's an Asian server and you are in Europe

https://canary.status.im/icingaweb2/dashboard
Sign In

thanks @chadyj! 

@yenda unfortunately, I do not have client logs from that session where app connected me to that mailserver (TF is gone). I will try to repro it later today

> It changes mail server after 2 timeouts of 30s. Is it not responsive or just very slow ? Provide some logs please. My guess is that it is just very slow because it's an Asian server and you are in Europe

@yenda unfortunately, I cannot replicate auto connecting to the unresponsive mailserver at this moment.

Btw, looks like `mail-02.ac-cn-hongkong-c.eth.beta` may also have some issues. Canary says it's UP but I do not receive any historical messages from this mailserver. I see "Fetching messages" appearing from time to time. Works fine when I switch to another mailserver. [Here is my logcat](https://gist.github.com/lukaszfryc/5126aab93a8b4d6a81d9ecc8561fbfaf).

This should be in status-go btw. 

We have [metrics](https://prometheus.status.im/graph?g0.range_input=1h&g0.expr=rate(geth_mailserver_archivedEnvelopes_overall%7Bfleet%3D%22eth.beta%22%2Ccontainer%3D~%22statusd-mail.*%22%7D%5B10m%5D)&g0.tab=0) that actually shows that mail servers in HK (mail-01.ac-cn-hongkong-c.eth.beta and mail-03.ac-cn-hongkong-c.eth.beta) are doing poorly (red and blue respectively). 

![screen shot 2018-10-16 at 15 04 39](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/277870/47018413-f6a0ee00-d154-11e8-80c6-bdec0c8c722f.png)

So the problem should be most visible for mail-01.ac-cn-hongkong-c.eth.beta and less visible for mail-03.ac-cn-hongkong-c.eth.beta. mail-02.ac-cn-hongkong-c.eth.beta should operate just fine.

Sorry, must have lost this one in all the github notifications.

![cpu](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2212681/47105940-5d84dc80-d213-11e8-8b6b-ba6598c05d3f.png)
![load](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2212681/47105942-607fcd00-d213-11e8-8662-707de4004f12.png)
![mem](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2212681/47105943-607fcd00-d213-11e8-9b22-3f9c61fbe9bb.png)
![net](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2212681/47105944-607fcd00-d213-11e8-9c95-6e3f636a8d9b.png)

It does seem like they have CPU and load spikes from time to time, like so:
![cpu_24h](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2212681/47106056-a3da3b80-d213-11e8-903d-7d17a8a03341.png)
![load_24h](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2212681/47106057-a3da3b80-d213-11e8-8eb4-fd4467e6647c.png)

The size of instance we are using there are `ecs.t5-lc1m2.small` which means:

Instance type | vCPU | Memory (GiB) | CPU credits/hour | Max CPU credit balance | Avg baseline CPU performance
-- | -- | -- | -- | -- | --
__ecs.t5-lc1m2.small__ | 1 | 2.0 | 6 | 144 | 10%
ecs.t5-lc1m2.large | 2 | 4.0 | 12 | 288 | 10%

@adambabik do you think I should bump it to a 2 CPU instance like `ecs.t5-lc1m2.large`?

@jakubgs it's interesting that we use the same type of servers but the performance is so different... We can bump them to 2 vCPU and 4 GB mem and see if that helps. 

When I sshed on one of HK machine, it was visible that the server is struggling with CPU (load was high and everything was super slow).

It might be related to the concept of CPU credits that exists in Alibaba Cloud:
https://www.alibabacloud.com/help/doc-detail/59977.htm

>Each type of t5 instance provides a baseline level of CPU computing performance, which means that each vCPU core of an instance provides a maximum usage under normal workloads. For example, when the ecs.t5-lc1m2.small instance runs under normal workloads, the maximum CPU usage is 10%.

>Each t5 instance acquires CPU credits at a fixed rate based on the baseline CPU computing performance. A CPU credit is the unit for measuring computing performance, which is related to the number of vCPU cores, CPU usage, and running time. For example:

>t5 instances acquire CPU credits at 1-minute granularity. The CPU credit acquisition rate indicates CPU credits acquired by a t5 instance per unit time (minute). It is determined by the baseline CPU computing performance. The calculation formula is as follows:

So I've decided to try a different family of instances - `sn1ne` - meaning "compute optimized type family with enhanced network performance".

https://www.alibabacloud.com/help/doc-detail/25378.htm#sn1ne

Instance type | vCPU | Memory (GiB) | Local disks (GiB)* | Bandwidth (Gbit/s)** | Packet forwarding rate (Thousand pps)*** | NIC queues**** | ENIs*****
-- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | --
ecs.sn1ne.large | 2 | 4.0 | N/A | 1.0 | 300 | 2 | 2

This type does not have a CPU credit system like `t5-lc1m2` family, so we'll see what happens.

Done and deployed: https://github.com/status-im/infra-eth-cluster/commit/b1ba291a86ecab319cb2b27c1395ddd32342634f

We'll see how the hosts will behave in thd coming days. But I think this issue shows that we either need more performance metrics from whisper/mail nodes or we need more graphs for already existing metrics, to measure performance of not just hosts but the nodes themselves.

I've added the `geth_mailserver_archivedEnvelopes_overall` metric Adam used to the dashboard as a start:
https://grafana.status.im/d/wV77E-4mz/statusd-metrics?orgId=1&from=1540148109197&to=1540191309197&var-host=mail.*&var-fleet=beta&var-dc=ac-cn-hongkong-c&var-dc=do-ams3&var-dc=gc-us-central1-a

Done and deployed: https://github.com/status-im/infra-eth-cluster/commit/b1ba291a86ecab319cb2b27c1395ddd32342634f

We'll see how the hosts will behave in thd coming days. But I think this issue shows that we either need more performance metrics from whisper/mail nodes or we need more graphs for already existing metrics, to measure performance of not just hosts but the nodes themselves.

I've added the `geth_mailserver_archivedEnvelopes_overall` metric Adam used to the dashboard as a start:
https://grafana.status.im/d/wV77E-4mz/statusd-metrics?orgId=1&from=1540148109197&to=1540191309197&var-host=mail.*&var-fleet=beta&var-dc=ac-cn-hongkong-c&var-dc=do-ams3&var-dc=gc-us-central1-a
The HK mailserver works fine now. I'm closing this issue.
Closing this issue as the HK mailserver works fine now.
Closing this issue as the HK mailserver works fine now.
Closing this issue as the HK mailserver works fine now.
